title: Higher ping than normal (60 -> 110 for me) through iinet
body:
My isp is Internode, but a friend with Adam internet (also goes though iinet) is having the same problem. Every other application has normal latency. Here's a tracert:

Tracing route to 103.240.227.254 over a maximum of 30 hops

  1     5 ms     9 ms     8 ms  TP-LINK.Home [192.168.1.1]
  2    32 ms    36 ms    35 ms  lns21.adl6.on.ii.net [203.16.215.175]
  3    33 ms    37 ms    35 ms  te0-2-0.cr1.adl2.on.ii.net [203.16.212.24]
  4   108 ms   114 ms   116 ms  ae0.cr1.adl6.on.ii.net [150.101.33.3]
  5   122 ms   130 ms   117 ms  ae4.br1.syd7.on.ii.net [150.101.33.34]
  6   114 ms   116 ms   114 ms  ae0.br1.syd4.on.ii.net [150.101.33.14]
  7     *        *      116 ms  as6507.nsw.ix.asn.au [218.100.52.50]
  8   127 ms   112 ms     *     104.160.156.37
  9   116 ms   116 ms   116 ms  104.160.156.105
 10     *        *        *     Request timed out.
 11     *        *        *     Request timed out.
 12     *        *        *     Request timed out.
 13     *        *        *     Request timed out.
 14     *        *        *     Request timed out.
 15     *        *        *     Request timed out.
 16     *        *        *     Request timed out.

Anyone else having the same problem?

replies.body: I'm having this same issue, did anyone find a fix?

I'm with IINET, currently experiencing 130ish ping, where I normally have 50-60. Have confirmed absolutely nothing else is running on the network.

Are you based in WA or SA? I'll paste what I just found on the IINET website:
> 
> "Service External Connectivity Type Fault (Serious) Started 5 hours ago
> Event ID 4565295 Status Happening now Ending in 10 hours
> Affected Service(s)
> 
> External Connectivity
> 
> Some Broadband customers in Western Australia & South Australia may experience higher than usual latency & packet loss. This may cause slower than usual browsing speeds. 
> 
> Technical Summary
> 
> Loss of traffic across our network partner's domestic transit links has been observed.
> Resolution
> 
> Our network partner has advised that the origin of the issue has been isolated to a remote SA area and have dispatched field technicians to the site. 
> Due to the remote location, it will take some time for technicians to arrive."

So basically some node / station in remote SA is screwing up and either flooding the network with garbage, or causing collisions. I assume.
